text: Form of ל־‎ (l'-) including first-person singular personal pronoun as object: me

defs.etymology:
The possessed forms of של were a common Canaanite construction seen also, for example, in Punic 𐤔𐤋𐤉‎ (šly /sillī/, “my”) and Phoenician 𐤀𐤔 𐤋𐤉‎ (ʾš ly /ʔas lī/, “my”). These were derived from the relative pronoun *ʔas or prefix *-ʔas in combination with the dative prefix *-l, hence the Hebrew is equivalent to ש־‎ (she, “which”) +‎ ל־‎ (l, “to”), thus “which [belongs] to”.
The first use of של as a possessive marker in Hebrew is attested in late parts of the Hebrew Bible, but then still preceded by, and in addition to, a possessive suffix (cf. Canticles 1:6; 3:7). In Mishnaic Hebrew, של־‎ (shel'-) becomes a true preposition by back-formation. The standalone spelling is a more recent innovation, but the pronoun-including forms are unchanged (which may be seen both in their gemination of the ל, and in the unusual forms of the second- and third-person masculine and feminine plural pronominal suffixes, otherwise found only in the inflections of ל־‎ (l'-) and ב־‎ (b'-)).

text: Of, belonging to, owned by, pertaining to.

text: נָכוֹן • (nakhón) (feminine נְכוֹנָה‎, masculine plural נְכוֹנִים‎, feminine plural נְכוֹנוֹת‎)
(of a statement or claim) Right, correct.
examples: אד איגנורנטיום, "טיעון מן הבורות", הוא טיעון מקבוצת כשלי הסחה בו נטען שבגלל שמשהו לא הוכח ככזב, הרי שהוא נכון.‎ — ad ignorántium, "tiún min haborút", hu tiún mikvutzát kishlei hasikhá bo nit'án shebiglál shemáshehu lo hukhákh k'khazáv, haréi shehú nakhón. — Ad ignorantium, "argument from ignorance", is an argument from the group of failures of diversion  in which it is assumed that because something isn't proven to be false, therefore it is true.

עשית את הדבר הנכון בכך שהחזרת את הפריט האבוד לבעליו.‎ — asít et hadavár hanakhón b'khakh shehekhzárt et haprít ha'avúd l'va'aláv. — You did the right thing in returning  the lost article to its owner.

text: Yes, true; used to express agreement with a fact.
examples: נכון, פשוט לא שמתי לב לשגיאתי.‎ — Nakhón, pashút lo sámti lev lish'giatí. — Yes, I just didn't notice my mistake.

defs.etymology: From the root י־ד־ה‎ (y-d-); closely related to the verb הוֹדָה‎ (hodá, “to acknowledge, to thank”). Compare Classical Syriac ܬܘܕܝ‎.

examples: ‏שֵׁשׁ וָחֵצִי, שֶׁבַע, שְׁמוֹנֶה, בֹּקֶר יוֹם רִאשׁוֹן / לֹא רוֹצֶה לִשְׁמֹעַ רַדְיוֹ, לֹא לִקְרֹא עִתּוֹן / עוֹד מְעַט עוֹמֵד לָרֶדֶת גֶּשֶׁם שִׁטָּפוֹן / לוּ יָכֹלְתִּי עַכְשָׁו רָק לִישֹׁן‎‎Six-thirty, seven, eight, on a Sunday Morning / I don't want to listen to the radio, nor read a newspaper / Soon torrential rain will start coming down / If only I could just sleep right now
Six-thirty, seven, eight, on a Sunday Morning / I don't want to listen to the radio, nor read a newspaper / Soon torrential rain will start coming down / If only I could just sleep right now

text: Form of ל־‎ (l'-) including third-person masculine singular personal pronoun as object.
examples: ‏מתעורר למציאות שונה, זה קשה לו, זה כואב לו‎‎waking up to a different reality, it's difficult for him, it hurts him

text: Form of ל־‎ (l-) including first-person plural personal pronoun as object.
(interrogative pronoun) who, what person or persons.
(relative pronoun) the person or persons that.

defs.etymology: From Proto-Semitic *šim-, from Proto-Afroasiatic *sim- (“name”). Cognate with Arabic اسم‎ (ism, “name”).

text: שֵׁם • (shém) m (plural indefinite שֵׁמוֹת‎, singular construct שֵׁם־, plural construct שְׁמוֹת־‎)
examples: ‏לְכָל אִישׁ יֵשׁ שֵׁם שֶׁנָּתַן לוֹ אֱלֹהִים וְנָתְנוּ לוֹ אָבִיו וְאִמּוֹ, / לְכָל אִישׁ יֵשׁ שֵׁם שֶׁנָּתְנוּ לוֹ קוֹמָתוֹ וְאֹפֶן חִיּוּכוֹ וְנָתַן לוֹ הָאָרִיג,  […] ‎Every person has a name that God gave him and that his father and mother gave him / Every person has a name that his stature and his way of smiling gave him and that the fabric gave him  […]

text: חושב \ חֻשַּׁב • (khusháv) (pu'al construction, active counterpart חישב \ חִשֵּׁב‎)
Masculine singular present participle and present tense of חָשַׁב‎ (khasháv).
examples: ‏אני חושב, משמע אני קיים‎ ― aní khoshév, mash'má aní qayám ― I think, meaning that I exist.

‏אִם כֵּן, לָמָּה אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים עַד חֲצוֹת, כְּדֵי לְהַרְחִיק אֶת הָאָדָם מִן הָעֲבֵרָה:‎‎Im ken, lamah ʾamru ḥakhamim ʿad ḥatsot? K'dei l'harḥiq ʾet haʾadam min haʿaverah.If so, why did the Sages say "until midnight?" In order to distance humankind from transgression.
Im ken, lamah ʾamru ḥakhamim ʿad ḥatsot? K'dei l'harḥiq ʾet haʾadam min haʿaverah.
If so, why did the Sages say "until midnight?" In order to distance humankind from transgression.

text: sufficient or appropriate for, sufficiently or appropriately for
examples: ‏אָכַל כְּדֵי צָרְכּוֹ‎ ― achál k'de tsorkó ― he ate so as to suffice for his need
‏כְּדֵי שְׁתִיַת רְבִיעִית‎ ― k'de sh'tiyát r'viít ― sufficient [time] for the drinking of a quarter[-log]

וְהִפִּילוֹ הַשֹּׁפֵט וְהִכָּהוּ לְפָנָיו כְּדֵי רִשְׁעָתוֹ בְּמִסְפָּרv'hipiló hashofét v'hikáhu l'fanav k'de rish'ató b'mispárthe judge shall make him lean over, and have him flogged with a fixed number of lashes for his crime.

text: (countable referents) several, a few, some; (uncountable referents) some
examples: ‏כמה אנשים גרים שם?‎‎káma anashím garím sham?How many people live there?
káma anashím garím sham?
How many people live there?
‏עוד כמה סידורים אתה תקנה?‎‎od káma sidurím atá tikné?
od káma sidurím atá tikné?
‏אכלנו כמה תמרים.‎‎akhálnu káma t'marím.We ate several dates.
akhálnu káma t'marím.
We ate several dates.
‏יש פה בעיר כמה אנשים שמדברים עברית.‎‎yesh po ba-ír káma anashím she-m'dab'rim ivrít.There are several people here in the town who speak Hebrew.
yesh po ba-ír káma anashím she-m'dab'rim ivrít.

text: How, how much, to what extent.
examples: כמה את אוהבת פיצה?‎ — káma at ohévet pítsa? — How much do you love pizza?

text: כָּמַהּ • (kamáh) (pa'al construction, infinitive לכמוה \ לִכְמֹהַּ‎, present כָּמֵהַּ, future יִכְמַהּ‎)
examples: ‏אֱלֹהִים אֵלִי אַתָּה אֲשַׁחֲרֶךָּ צָמְאָה לְךָ נַפְשִׁי כָּמַהּ לְךָ בְשָׂרִי בְּאֶרֶץ־צִיָּה וְעָיֵף בְּלִי־מָיִם׃‎‎'elohím 'elí 'atá 'ashakharéka tsam'á l'khá nafshí kamáh l'khá v'sarí b'érets-tsiyá v'ayéf b'li-máyim.ʾĕlōhīm ʾēlī ʾattā ʾăšaḥărékkā ṣāməʾā ləḵā nap̄šī kāmah ləḵā ḇəśārī bəʾéreṣ-ṣiyyā wəʿāyēp̄ bəlī-mā́yim.O God, Thou art my God, earnestly will I seek Thee; my soul thirsteth for Thee, my flesh longeth for Thee, in a dry and weary land, where no water is.

'elohím 'elí 'atá 'ashakharéka tsam'á l'khá nafshí kamáh l'khá v'sarí b'érets-tsiyá v'ayéf b'li-máyim.ʾĕlōhīm ʾēlī ʾattā ʾăšaḥărékkā ṣāməʾā ləḵā nap̄šī kāmah ləḵā ḇəśārī bəʾéreṣ-ṣiyyā wəʿāyēp̄ bəlī-mā́yim.
O God, Thou art my God, earnestly will I seek Thee; my soul thirsteth for Thee, my flesh longeth for Thee, in a dry and weary land, where no water is.

text: כָּמֵהַּ • (kaméah) (feminine כְּמֵהָה‎, masculine plural כְּמֵהִים‎, feminine plural כְּמֵהוֹת‎)
פָּשׁוּט • (pashút) (feminine פְּשׁוּטָה‎, masculine plural פְּשׁוּטִים‎, feminine plural פְּשׁוּטוֹת‎)
Form of אֵת‎ (et) including third-person feminine singular personal pronoun as object: she, it.

examples: המלוה את חברו על המשכון ואבד המשכון אמר לו סלע הלויתיך עליו ושקל היה שוה והלה אומר לא כי אלא סלע הלויתני עליו וסלע היה שוה […] One who lends to his friend against collateral and the collateral is gone: [If] he told him "I lent you a sela against it, and it was worth a shekel" and the other says "not so; rather, you lent me a sela against it and it was worth a sela" […]

text: (dated or formal) that; used to introduce declarative content clauses
(archaic) when, as, at the time that

words: (because): בִּגְלַל שֶׁ־‎ (biglál she-), משום ש־‎ (mishúm she-), מִפְּנֵי שֶׁ־‎ (mip'néi she-)

examples: ‏הלכתי למכולת לקנות שקית חלב כי אמי ביקשה ממני.‎‎halákhti lamakólet liknót sakít khaláv kí 'imí bik'shá miméni.I went to the grocery store to buy a bag of milk because my mother asked me to.

‏השמש נמצאת עכשיו במזרח, כי זוהי שעת זריחתה.‎‎hashémesh nimtsét 'akhsháv bamizrákh, kí zóhi sh'át z'rikhatáh.The sun is in the east now, for this is the hour of its rising.
hashémesh nimtsét 'akhsháv bamizrákh, kí zóhi sh'át z'rikhatáh.

‏המורה הודיעה כי מחר יתקיים יום ספורט בית־ספרי.‎‎hamorá hodí'a ki makhár yitkayém yóm spórt beit-sifrí.The teacher announced that tomorrow will be a school sports day.
hamorá hodí'a ki makhár yitkayém yóm spórt beit-sifrí.

‏על השלט נכתב כי אסור להפריע את מנוחת הדיירים בין 2 ל־4 בצהריים.‎‎'al hashélet nikhtáv kí 'asúr l'hafría' 'et m'nukhát hadayarím bein 2 l'-4 batsohoráyim.The sign says  that [it is] forbidden to disturb the tenants' rest between 2 and 4 in the afternoon.
'al hashélet nikhtáv kí 'asúr l'hafría' 'et m'nukhát hadayarím bein 2 l'-4 batsohoráyim.
The sign says  that [it is] forbidden to disturb the tenants' rest between 2 and 4 in the afternoon.

‏כֵּיצַד מוֹשְׁחִין אֶת הַמְּלָכִים? כְּמִין נֵזֶר. וְאֶת הַכֹּהֲנִים? כְּמִין כִּי. מַאי כְּמִין כִּי? אָמַר רַב מְנַשְּׁיָא בַּר גַּדָּא, כְּמִין כַּף יְוָנִי.‎‎Keitsad moshḥin et ha-mlakhim? K-min nézer. V-et ha-kohanim? K-min ki. Mai k-min ki? Amar Rav M'nashya bar Gadda, k-min kaf y'vani.In what way are kings anointed? Like a crown. And priests? Like a chi. What does "like a chi" mean? Says Rav Menashya bar Gadda, like the Greek version of kaph.
Keitsad moshḥin et ha-mlakhim? K-min nézer. V-et ha-kohanim? K-min ki. Mai k-min ki? Amar Rav M'nashya bar Gadda, k-min kaf y'vani.
In what way are kings anointed? Like a crown. And priests? Like a chi. What does "like a chi" mean? Says Rav Menashya bar Gadda, like the Greek version of kaph.

‏וְהָיָה תַחַת בֹּשֶׂם מַק יִהְיֶה וְתַחַת חֲגוֹרָה נִקְפָּה וְתַחַת מַעֲשֶׂה מִקְשֶׁה קָרְחָה וְתַחַת פְּתִיגִיל מַחֲגֹרֶת שָׂק כִּי תַחַת יֹפִי‎Və–hayah táḥat bósem maq yihyeh, və-táḥat ḥagorah niqpah, və-táḥat ma’aseh miqsheh qorḥah, və-táḥat pətigil makhagóreth saq, ki táḥat yófi.And it shall come to pass, that Instead of sweet spices there shall be rottenness; And instead of a girdle rags; And instead of curled hair baldness; And instead of a stomacher a girding of sackcloth; Branding instead of beauty.
Və–hayah táḥat bósem maq yihyeh, və-táḥat ḥagorah niqpah, və-táḥat ma’aseh miqsheh qorḥah, və-táḥat pətigil makhagóreth saq, ki táḥat yófi.

And it shall come to pass, that Instead of sweet spices there shall be rottenness; And instead of a girdle rags; And instead of curled hair baldness; And instead of a stomacher a girding of sackcloth; Branding instead of beauty.

‏אִם־עַל־פִּ֭יךָ יַגְבִּ֣יהַּ נָ֑שֶׁר וְ֝כִ֗י יָרִ֥ים קִנֹּֽו‎Is it upon your behest that the eagle and the vulture soars and makes his nest high? Or as with the particle above: Is it upon your behest that the eagle soars, and yea, makes his nest high?

text: Also, too, additionally; used to connect details in a list.
Also, additionally, in addition, further, besides, on top of that.
Even (though, if); despite the fact that.
examples: ‏לטיול יצאו רותי, דני וגם אני.‎‎ ― latiyúl yatz'ú rúti, dáni, v'gám aní. ―  To the trip went out Ruthy, Danny, and also me. —  Ruthy, Danny, and I went out for the trip.
‏אין לי חשק לצאת הערב, יורד גשם וגם אני מאוד עייף.‎‎ ― ein li khéshek latzét ha'érev, yoréd géshem v'gám aní m'ód ayéf. ― I don't want to go out tonight, it's raining and also I'm very tired.
‏אבא תמיד מקריא לי סיפור לפני השינה, גם כשהוא מאוד עסוק.‎‎ába tamíd makrí li sipúr lifnéi hasheiná, gam k'shehú m'ód asúk.Dad always reads me a story at bed-time , even when he's very busy.

‏גַּם כִּי־אֵלֵךְ בְּגֵיא צַלְמָוֶת לֹא־אִירָא רָע כִּי־אַתָּה עִמָּדִי שִׁבְטְךָ וּמִשְׁעַנְתֶּךָ הֵמָּה יְנַחֲמֻנִי׃‎‎gam ki elékh b'géi tsalmávet lo-irá ra ki-atá imadí shivt'khá umish'antékha hemá y'nakhamúni.Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.

text: Already: before now, or before then.

words: (already, before now, before then): עדיין \ עֲדַיִן‎ (adáyin, “still”), עוֹד (לֹא)‎ (ód (ló), “(not) yet”)

examples: ‏היא כבר גמרה!‎‎ ― hí k'vár gam'rá! ― She's already finished!
‏עד שחשבתי על זה, זה כבר לא היה רלוונטי.‎‎ ― ád shekhashávti ál ze, ze k'vár ló hayá relevánti. ― By the time I thought of it, it was already irrelevant.
‏כבר אז ידעו.‎‎ ― k'vár áz yad'ú. ― They knew even then.
‏רק רגע, אני כבר בא.‎‎ ― rák réga, aní k'vár bá. ―  Just a moment, I'm already coming. —  Just a moment, I'll be right there/right back.
‏יחליטו כבר בדצמבר.‎‎ ― yakhlítu k'vár b'detsémber. ― They'll already decide in December.

defs.etymology: Cognate with Akkadian 𒈠𒀪𒁕 (ma'du), Ugaritic 𐎎𐎄 (mid, mud), Arabic مُدَّة‎ (mudda).

examples: ‏נעים מאוד.‎‎ ― na'ím m'ód. ―  Very pleasant. —  Pleased to meet you.

text: מאוד \ מְאֹד • (m'ód) m (no plural forms, singular construct מאוד \ מְאֹד־)
examples: ‏וְאָהַבְתָּ אֵת ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ בְּכָל לְבָבְךָ וּבְכָל נַפְשְׁךָ וּבְכָל מְאֹדֶךָ‎‎v' ahavta et H' eloheikha b'khol l'vavkha uvkhol nafsh'kha uvkhol m'odekhaAnd thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thine heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy might.

defs.etymology: לְ־‎ (l'-, “to, for”) +‎ פְּנֵי‎ (p'néi, “face of”), the latter being the construct form of פָּנִים‎ (paním, “face”).

text: Before, in advance of, prior to.
(לְפָנַי, l'fanáy) Form of לִפְנֵי‎ (lifnéy) including first-person singular personal pronoun as object.
examples: ‏דקה לפני הסוף‎ ― daká lif'néi hasóf ― a minute before the end
‏לפני שהגעת‎ ― lif'néi shehigá'at ― before you arrived
‏יורד לפני התיבה‎ ― yoréd lifnéi hateivá ― going down in front of the ark
‏מודה אני לפניך‎‎ ― modé aní l'fanécha ― I give thanks before you
‏לפני יומיים‎ ― lif'néi yomáyim ― two days ago

defs.etymology:

text: פַּעַם • (pá'am) f (dual indefinite פעמיים \ פַּעֲמַיִם‎, plural indefinite פְּעָמִים‎, singular construct פַּעַם־, plural construct פַּעֲמֵי־‎) [pattern: קֶטֶל]
A time: an instance, an occurrence.
A step, a footstep, a pace: an instance of stepping with the foot.
A stroke, a beat, as a heartbeat.
(used adverbially) Once, at one time, in the past.

examples: אמרתי לך פעם שאמא שלך, היא לא ממש אמא נורמלית

זְמַן • (zmán) m (plural indefinite זְמַנִּים‎, singular construct זְמַן־, plural construct זְמַנֵּי־‎)

‏הרצה קבעה זמן מצוין.‎‎ ― haratsá kav'á z'mán m'tsuyán. ― The runner set an excellent time.

examples: When God began creating the heaven and the earth, while the earth was yet empty and formless and darkness was over the surface of the abyss, while the spirit of God hovered over the water's surface, God said: "There be light" and there was light.

text: אלוהים \ אֱלֹהִים • (elohím) m (singular construct אלוהי \ אֱלֹהֵי־‎)
